questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : LARGE LANGUAGE MODELS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: Transformers process input tokens:
question_texts: Transformers process input tokens:

options.option_text: One at a time (sequentially)
In reverse order
All at once (in parallel)
Only after seeing the full input

questions.question_text_1: What is the purpose of the softmax function in the attention mechanism?
question_texts: What is the purpose of the softmax function in the attention mechanism?

options.option_text: Normalize attention scores to a probability distribution
Add non-linearity to the model
To predict the correct class for the loss function
Remove redundant features from the input

questions.question_text_1: What is the main difference between GPT and BERT pre-training objectives?
question_texts: What is the main difference between GPT and BERT pre-training objectives?

options.option_text: GPT uses Masked Language Modeling, BERT uses Causal Language Modeling
GPT uses Causal Language Modeling, BERT uses Masked Language Modeling
Both use Masked Language Modeling
Both use Causal Language Modeling

questions.question_text_1: In Top-K sampling for language generation, increasing the value of K typically has which of the following effects?
question_texts: In Top-K sampling for language generation, increasing the value of K typically has which of the following effects?

options.option_text: It makes the output more deterministic and repetitive.
It reduces the probability of selecting high-frequency words.
It increases the diversity of the generated text but may reduce coherence if Kis too large.
It guarantees grammatical correctness by focusing on top-ranked tokens only.

questions.question_text_1: Why are residual connections important in transformer architectures?
question_texts: Why are residual connections important in transformer architectures?

options.option_text: They reduce memory consumption.
They add extra cost of compute by adding batch normalization.
They help in training deep networks by enabling gradient flow.
They remove the need for layer normalization.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements are true regarding causal language modeling (CLM)?
question_texts: Which of the following statements are true regarding causal language modeling (CLM)?

options.option_text: The model only attends to past and current tokens during training.
The model is trained by predicting the next token in a sequence.
The model uses bidirectional context.
The CLM objective is commonly used for encoder-only models.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are valid reasons why transformer-based large language models are widely used in natural language processing?
question_texts: Which of the following are valid reasons why transformer-based large language models are widely used in natural language processing?

options.option_text: Transformers process input sequences in parallel, enabling faster training.
They use recurrence to remember long-term dependencies more effectivelythan LSTMs.
Transformers are limited to short text inputs due to their architecture.
Large transformer models can be fine-tuned for various NLP tasks using asingle pre-trained model.

questions.question_text_1: Which elements are included in BERT’s input representation for Next Sentence Prediction?
question_texts: Which elements are included in BERT’s input representation for Next Sentence Prediction?

questions.question_text_1: How does Top-p (nucleus) sampling differ from Top-K sampling in language generation?
question_texts: How does Top-p (nucleus) sampling differ from Top-K sampling in language generation?

options.option_text: It samples only from a fixed number of tokens at each step.
It samples from the smallest set of tokens whose cumulative probabilityexceeds p.
It always selects the top-p tokens with equal probability.
It guarantees diversity by selecting all low-probability tokens.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Core Topics and Concepts

1. **Transformer Architecture**
   - **Parallel Processing**: Transformers process input tokens in parallel, which enables faster training.
   - **Attention Mechanism**: The attention mechanism allows the model to focus on different parts of the input sequence.
   - **Residual Connections**: These help in training deep networks by enabling gradient flow.

2. **Attention Mechanisms**
   - **Softmax Function**: Used to normalize attention scores to a probability distribution.
   - **Scaled Dot-Product Attention**: Computes attention scores as \( \text{softmax}\left( \frac{Q^T K}{\sqrt{d_k}} \right) V^T \).

3. **Pre-training Objectives**
   - **Causal Language Modeling (CLM)**: Used in models like GPT, where the model predicts the next token in a sequence.
   - **Masked Language Modeling (MLM)**: Used in models like BERT, where the model predicts masked tokens in a sequence.

4. **Sampling Techniques**
   - **Top-K Sampling**: Samples from the top K most probable tokens.
   - **Top-p (Nucleus) Sampling**: Samples from the smallest set of tokens whose cumulative probability exceeds p.

5. **Embeddings**
   - **Word Embeddings**: Represent words in a continuous vector space.
   - **Position Embeddings**: Use sinusoidal functions to encode the position of tokens in a sequence.
     - \( PE(pos, 2i) = \sin\left( \frac{pos}{10000^{2i/d_{model}}} \right) \)
     - \( PE(pos, 2i + 1) = \cos\left( \frac{pos}{10000^{2i/d_{model}}} \right) \)

6. **Layer Normalization**
   - **Equations**:
     - \( \mu_l = \frac{1}{H} \sum_{i=1}^{H} x_i \)
     - \( \sigma_l = \sqrt{\frac{1}{H} \sum_{i=1}^{H} (x_i - \mu_l)^2} \)
     - \( \hat{x_i} = \frac{x_i - \mu_l}{\sqrt{\sigma_l^2 + \epsilon}} \)
     - \( \hat{y_i} = \gamma \hat{x_i} + \beta \)

7. **Multi-Head Attention**
   - **Concatenation and Projection**: Outputs from multiple attention heads are concatenated and projected using a weight matrix \( W_O \).

8. **Exhaustive Search and Probability Distributions**
   - **Conditional Probability Distribution**: Used in sequence generation to predict the next token based on previous tokens.
   - **Total Sequences**: Calculated based on the number of tokens and the length of the sequence.

#### Important Equations

1. **Position Embeddings**:
   \[
   PE(pos, 2i) = \sin\left( \frac{pos}{10000^{2i/d_{model}}} \right)
   \]
   \[
   PE(pos, 2i + 1) = \cos\left( \frac{pos}{10000^{2i/d_{model}}} \right)
   \]

2. **Layer Normalization**:
   \[
   \mu_l = \frac{1}{H} \sum_{i=1}^{H} x_i
   \]
   \[
   \sigma_l = \sqrt{\frac{1}{H} \sum_{i=1}^{H} (x_i - \mu_l)^2}
   \]
   \[
   \hat{x_i} = \frac{x_i - \mu_l}{\sqrt{\sigma_l^2 + \epsilon}}
   \]
   \[
   \hat{y_i} = \gamma \hat{x_i} + \beta
   \]

3. **Scaled Dot-Product Attention**:
   \[
   \text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}\left( \frac{Q^T K}{\sqrt{d_k}} \right) V^T
   \]

4. **Softmax Function**:
   \[
   P(token) = \frac{e^{\text{Scaled Logit}}}{\sum_{i} e^{\text{Scaled Logit}_i}}
   \]

5. **Temperature Scaling**:
   \[
   \text{Scaled Logit} = \frac{\text{Logit}}{T}
   \]

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Transformer Architecture] --> B[Parallel Processing]
    A --> C[Attention Mechanism]
    A --> D[Residual Connections]
    C --> E[Softmax Function]
    C --> F[Scaled Dot-Product Attention]
    A --> G[Pre-training Objectives]
    G --> H[Causal Language Modeling]
    G --> I[Masked Language Modeling]
    A --> J[Sampling Techniques]
    J --> K[Top-K Sampling]
    J --> L[Top-p Sampling]
    A --> M[Embeddings]
    M --> N[Word Embeddings]
    M --> O[Position Embeddings]
    A --> P[Layer Normalization]
    P --> Q[Mean Calculation]
    P --> R[Standard Deviation Calculation]
    P --> S[Normalization]
    P --> T[Scaling and Shifting]
    A --> U[Multi-Head Attention]
    U --> V[Concatenation]
    U --> W[Projection]
    A --> X[Exhaustive Search]
    X --> Y[Conditional Probability Distribution]
    X --> Z[Total Sequences]
```

```mermaid
graph TD;
    E[Softmax Function] --> AA[Normalize Attention Scores]
    F[Scaled Dot-Product Attention] --> AB[Compute Attention Scores]
    H[Causal Language Modeling] --> AC[Predict Next Token]
    I[Masked Language Modeling] --> AD[Predict Masked Tokens]
    K[Top-K Sampling] --> AE[Sample from Top K Tokens]
    L[Top-p Sampling] --> AF[Sample from Tokens Exceeding Probability p]
    N[Word Embeddings] --> AG[Represent Words in Vector Space]
    O[Position Embeddings] --> AH[Encode Token Positions]
    Q[Mean Calculation] --> AI[Calculate Mean of Inputs]
    R[Standard Deviation Calculation] --> AJ[Calculate Standard Deviation of Inputs]
    S[Normalization] --> AK[Normalize Inputs]
    T[Scaling and Shifting] --> AL[Scale and Shift Normalized Inputs]
    V[Concatenation] --> AM[Concatenate Attention Heads]
    W[Projection] --> AN[Project Concatenated Outputs]
    Y[Conditional Probability Distribution] --> AO[Predict Next Token]
    Z[Total Sequences] --> AP[Calculate Total Possible Sequences]
```

These graphs provide a visual representation of the relationships between the core topics, concepts, and principles essential for the exam.
